Award.AwardTitle: Ground Magnetometer Responses to Sudden Solar Wind Pressure Impulses Using a Global Magnetogram Technique
Award.AbstractNarration:
The dynamic variations in the geospace environment driven by solar wind produce space weather that can impact technology in space and on the ground. The impulsive response of the magnetosphere to solar wind shocks is a unique and easily identifiable component of this weather. This investigation is a 3-year data-analysis and modeling effort aimed at providing a better understanding of this fundamental response, the so-called geomagnetic sudden impulse (SI) phenomenon. It will apply newly developed techniques to synthesize global ground magnetometer observations and will also compare these observations with the results of global magnetosphere simulations driven by observed solar wind and interplanetary magnetic field parameters. Special focus will be on "atypical" SI events. The results of this study are expected to provide a more complete and more global (all latitudes and local times) understanding of the fundamental response of Earth's magnetosphere to externally imposed impulsive changes.

While formally submitted by Professor Clauer, the research effort has been conceived and formulated by Dr. Cai, an early career scientist at Virginia Polytechnic, who also will be leading and carrying out most of the work. Results from this research will inform our understanding in ways that improve our ability to model space weather, thereby enabling better predictions of space weather. As such, the results of this research effort are expected to be of direct benefit to society.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this research is to understand how the Earth’s magnetosphere and ionosphere respond to a unique upstream solar wind structure, i.e., sudden solar wind pressures increase. The objective is to examine whether the ground magnetic field disturbance pattern and the corresponding ionospheric equivalent current system have a dependence on the interplanetary magnetic field (IMF) orientations.
During the first year, the PI Dr. Cai concentrated on developing the analyzing software and building the magnetometer database. She also conducted initial case studies with the developed software. In the second year, Dr. Cai conducted a statistical study of the ground magnetic disturbance pattern with 139 solar wind sudden pressure increase events from 1998 to 2010. She found that the pattern does depend on solar wind conditions.There are approximately 45% events during which the dayside mid- and low-latitude stations observed negative magnetic disturbance. So these atypical response events are more common than originally thought
During the second year, Dr. Cai also worked with Dr. Yiqun Yu, who is a research scientist at Los Alamos National Laboratory, and did a few more numerical experiments. After examining the ionospheric equivalent current systems, they proposed that the negative magnetic responses are due to ionospheric convection pattern change as a result of IMF By orientation change. They identified several events and tried to have a full understanding of solar wind — magentosphere- ionosphere coupling with both global observations and numerical simulations.
Following the second year, Dr. Cai had not made the progress as planned due to the following two reasons. First, Dr. Cai was involved in an engineering project that would expand the current Super Dual Auroral Radar Network (SuperDARN) to mainland China. This project is a collaborative effort between the Center of Space Science and Engineering Research at Virgnia Tech (VT) and National Space Science Center in Beijing. She took an extended visit to Beijing in 2014 summer to provide support for developing the proposal, identify the potential radar site, and mentor a postdoc to conduct scientific research with SuperDARN data. Second Dr. Cai took senior research scientist position at NASA Langley Research Center in September 2014. Her research focus moved from magnetosphere and ionosphere to lower atmosphere. She still kept an adjunct faculty position at VT and continued her efforts in this research. However after months' trial Dr. Cai found it is unlikely to finish the project working only 2-8 hours a week.
Therefore Dr. Cai decided to transfer her PI responsibility to her Postdoc advisor Professor Robert Clauer at VT, who is also an expert of magnetospheric physics. They also requested a 12-month no-cost extension.  Shortly after this,  Dr. Michael Harbinger join the group and agreed to continue efforts under this award. Dr. Hartinger received his Ph.D. in Geophysics and Space Physics from UCLA in 2012 and just completed his NSFpostdoc training at the University of Michigan. He specializes in ultra low frequency (ULF) plasma waves in the near- Earth space environment with both ground-based and space-borne instruments.  The coupling of transient wave events is also one of his research interests.
